content: As (unfortunately) per usual, I'm reverting the difficulty back to medium following some feedback and due to a notably low success rate (25% at the time of this post).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: If terminator approves it I approves it.
He's like my best buddy

I ended up adding an example to the statement as suggested by @jddingemanse, @FredericLocquet and (in a way) @[4G]. This is the part added:

Example (Test 4):
2
ab

The points at distance less or equal to 2 of ab are:
- at distance 0: ab
- at distance 1: bb, aa, ac
- at distance 2: cb, ad, bc, ba

For a total of 8 points contained in the (closed) ball of center ab and radius 2.
Not easy to understand what to do. You should add to the statement the example given to [4G] ;-)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice, very unique puzzle. I am now looking to balls with a different perspective.

Very nice puzzle! I solved it, and I am willing to approve, but first some suggestions:
- I got quite confused by the +INF. It took me a while to understand that I do not need that at all - it is simply to make that any point within the ball is a string of equal length to center. Maybe the statement becomes easier to understand if you do not even discuss the case of different string lengths, and simply state that a ball consists of points being strings of equal length to the center?
- Anyway the length discussion ('length la, lb...') confused me at first because I mixed up distance and length in my head. That might be my stupidity, but the previous point might also resolve this.
- The three given examples could maybe be made more explicit to clarify the 'sum of the pairwise...' part. Something like: 'd("ab", "ac") = d("ac", "ab") = d("a", "a") + d("b", "c") = 0 + 1 = 1"
- Based on the single Test 1 example, it was still hard to get a grasp on what the task was. Maybe include a more explicit description of that example in your statement, something like: 'radius 1, center "a": there are two points in this string ball: "a" and "b", since d("a", "a") and d("a", "b") are <= 1.' And, possibly even include an example with a two-character-string center.

By the way, down in the comments, I thought about the difficulty level. I found it not easy, but maybe if you agree with and implement above suggestions, the task at hand becomes overly clear and solving it becomes more *easy*.

Goal section
* Suggest to change "!=" to "≠" and "==" to "=".

Constraints section
* Please change "len" to "length".

Thanks.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a great puzzle! The author has done a tremendous job distinguishing all aspects of the puzzle and the test cases are robust. What I like even more is how many concepts this reasonably easy puzzle explores. I thoroughly enjoyed the mental exercise required to think of points as strings and then determine a distance between two points by comparing the strings.

I feel like I've spent too much time on this puzzle to be a good judge of Easy vs Medium. I'll leave that discussion to future reviewers.

One last comment: You use the phrase "number of points" and also the phrase "amount of points". Obviously, it's a pretty little thing, but I think "number of points" sounds more appropriate for a discrete quantity.

Nice puzzle. I didn't dive too much into it yet, but I think the easy difficulty can encourage more people to give it a try. The first cases are easy to solve with a simple brute-force algorithm, and the next ones force you to think differently, to speed up the calculations.

I did change (again...) the difficulty back to easy, but I'm still not convinced. I keep saying to myself that the performance check is not challenging enough for medium but what do I know.

I'll submit it as it is, but I'm very open to change the difficulty if need so. As usual, feedback appreciated.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I don't get it.
Maybe it's my weak English but, I really don't get it.
Very interesting puzzle

Outstanding puzzle! I see you recently changed this from Medium to Easy. I think some folks might fight you on that, but I agree with Easy. I get it that recursion is never as easy as basic string manipulation, but this puzzle is pretty straightforward and allows the puzzler to test their knowledge of recursion without adding tremendous complexity.

A few comments:

I like title case for titles: String Balls (I like the puzzle a lot more than the name, but I haven't thought of anything better yet...)

I also like title case for test and validator names, but that's not critical of course.

I love your goal section. Very well done. The only part that you might look at rewording is "for i in range(la)". The rest of your write-up sounds very generic and/or mathematical. This one phrase seems very Python. Maybe something like, "for all index values (i) from 0 to la-1".

Very well done!

New things:

- Simplified statement and constraints
- Added tags
- Added picture (from https://www.quantamagazine.org/how-tadayuki-watanabe-solved-a-topological-mystery-about-spheres-20211026/)
- Difficulty is now easy (from medium)
- Reordered tests
- Updated solution
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
cool
Cool!
This puzzle seems nice, I'm looking forward playing with it.
For future reference: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/32619a01843ca4378db8c1eea43795527d31b

So my reasoning was that this one should be easier than the "fix the spaces" (labelled easy). Last time I checked, that one had around 40% success rate which I thought was low but ok... But now I just saw in the Chadok site that it sits at the second lowest success rate of all the easy puzzles... so basically I just convinced myself to at least put this one back to "medium", lol.

The funny thing is that I thought I was good at assessing the difficulty... but oh well.

There's nothing I can do with the title case for tests and validators.

If someone has a better title for the puzzle feel free to suggest it.

I'll fix that statement. You are right it's too pythonic lol.

No you are right that the statement is a bit too condensed.

Let me pick this example (Test 4):

2
ab
Expected solution: 8

The points are:
at distance 0: ab
at distance 1: bb, aa, ac
at distance 2: cb, ad, bc, ba

And, for example, cb is at distance 2 because (remember radius = ab):
d(a, c) = 2
d(b, b) = 0
d(ab, cb) = d(a, c) + d(b, b) = 2 + 0 = 2

Well, I'm puzzling on this contribution - and I like it - but I do not find it easy. I've managed to get a solution for something up to validator 9 (excluding validator 8 by the way - for some reason my solution passes test 8, test 9 and validator 9, but times out for  validator 8 - as well as for 10 and 11 of course). I find it hard to get my head around how to optimize my solution further.
When I get there, I will post some remarks regarding statement clarity, but for now I'd say the difficulty for me is *not* easy.

Changed "amount" to "number" in the output section.

Also thank you for the kind words in your other comment.
Fixed, thanks.

- 'We can extend <<d>> to strings as follows. Given two strings <<sa>>, <<sb>> of respective length <<la>>, <<lb>>: if <<la ≠ lb>>, then d(sa, sb) = <<+INF>>, and if <<la = lb>>, then d(sa, sb) is the <<sum of the pairwise d(sa[i], sb[i]) for all index values (i) from 0 to la-1>>. For example:
`
  d("ab", "ac") = d("ac", "ab") = 1
  d("a",  "ab") = +INF
  d("ac", "bb") = 2
`
We can now define a (closed) ball of [[center]] a given string and of (integer) [[radius]]. A point [[p]] (i.e. a string with letters in the alphabet) is inside the ball if d([[center]], [[p]]) <= [[radius]].'

---

-> 'We can extend <<d>> to strings <<of equal length>> as follows: given two strings sa, sb of equal length <<len>>, d(sa, sb) is the <<sum of the pairwise d(sa[i], sb[i]) for all index values (i) from 0 to len-1>>. For example:
`
  d("fb", "fd") = d("f", "f") + d("b", "d") = 0 + 2 = 2
  d("ab", "ac") = d("ac", "ab") = 1
  d("ac", "bb") = 2
`
We can now define a (closed) ball of [[center]] a given string and of (integer) [[radius]]. A point [[p]] (i.e. a string with letters in the alphabet and of same length as the center) is inside the ball if d([[center]], [[p]]) <= [[radius]].'

---

I think this covers the first 3 points. Not very fond of the wording but oh well.

Now for the fourth I'm reluctant to add an example because the first 4 tests (plus some parts of the statement) are literally examples themselves.

For the difficulty, I've read your other comments but I think I'll stick with easy for the moment. There's still many solutions that can pass this testset. I think the only way to get timed out is to straight up testing every word of same length and counting it depending on the distance.

My solution timed out not because I checked every word; I did check only the options that had a distance within radius, and stopped checking once I reached radius. I think my problem was that I stored a bit too much info along the way (e.g. for aa and radius 2 I iteratively moved from [0], [1], [2] to [0,0], [1,0], [2,0], [0,1], [1,1], ... -- keeping all lists with sum<=radius and counting the number of lists at the end). I actually don't know how to explain this clearly, but there are more ways to time out than only checking every word.

By the way, I agree your revised statement covers the first three points, good job, and as for the fourth point I understand your point and you have final say anyway :-).

Riight - I suddenly got an insight, it worked, and now in hindsight it looks easy. I see your dilemma.

Personally I could agree with 'medium' level for this contribution; the difficulty for me is in imagining what should happen. It is hard to get an image in your head of a 'string ball', so it is challenging to get a grasp on what steps are needed to get an answer. That is what for me makes this contribution not easy.

I think Medium also works. However, if you go Medium, I think you should turn the heat up a bit. For instance:

radius = 500

center = 'codingameisthebestsitetopracticeyourcodingandthatistheabsolutetruth'

Obviously, the numbers get big, so using MOD to produce reasonable answers would be best.

For this example:

answer % 1000000007 (probably needs 2nd party verification) = 569544136

Haha, you are probably right, although I still will go with medium for the moment for the reasons above. If some other users find it too easy then I'll change it (I really don't want to land in another sub 40% success rate).

I'm not even sure I'd know how to solve that one, seems interesting. Did you solve it?

If you're up for it, I'd love to play around with this a bit. For the "11. Big 2" test case, I'm clocking you right around 4000 ms compared to my 1 ms. Here's the really interesting part. As the radius and center get bigger and bigger, your time skyrockets, but my time slowly increases. I've seen a ton of your work, so I know you can get to the same speed I'm at.

Yes, my algorithm appears to solve the test case I proposed above. I feel pretty confident I'm doing the MOD correctly. I can't see anything right now that I might be doing wrong.

Bottom line is that I think this is a really cool puzzle that allows the puzzler to practice recursion, memoization and combinatorics. Play around with bigger test cases and see what you come up with!
Max 420 ms for the giant test case I have proposed by the way. I'm open to being wrong if I've screwed something up, but my algorithm seems solid to me.

I think I got it, I found the same result as you. Now I must pass the ball:

Edit: The string is so long that if I put it here it breaks the chat lol, it's just your original sentence copy pasted 3 times...

5000
codingameisthebestsitetopracticeyourcodingandthatistheabsolutetruth *3

Took: 3.3391sec
406675813

406675813 is confirmed. However, I'm in the CG IDE and I'm around 5.8 sec when I get a successful answer. 75% of the time, I'm timing out, so I maybe still have some optimization to do. Is your 3.3 sec time in the CG IDE?

I got my time for this one down to 0.32 ms.

5000 is too big for that string. The max non-infinite distance is only 3825, so the cheat code becomes: 26 ** len(center) % 1000000007
As for my recursion, etc., I'm pretty stumped as to why I'm taking almost double your time.

Ah lol the cheat code is smart. I guess since the furthest string away from the center is at most:

sum(max(c, 25 - c) for c in center)

you could change 5000 to sth like furthest - 10, which in this case is 3815, and I obtain:

Took: 3.3385sec
619433522

I don't do recursion, just an improved version of the "iterative" version down below. I get to 5.8s if I add another copy of the string, so we shouldn't be very far away.

Well, this really challenged me. I tossed out my recursive approach and started from scratch. After three complete failures, I finally came up with a solution for radius = 3815 and confirmed the answer = 619433522. I ran it about 20 times and all times were between 2400 ms and 3200 ms, very rarely over 3000.

One more suggestion. I added 6 characters to the string to push my recursive/memoization approach to timeout 100% of the time. I found the recursive approach way easier to write than what I came up with today, so I kind of like pushing that recursive approach to full timeout.

New string is:

radius = 3815
codingameisthebestsitetopracticeyourcodingandthatistheabsolutetruthbooyah * 3

answer = 72157018
most times are below 3600 ms with one outlier at 4100 and several just below 3000.

Like you, if I go to 4 times this new string, I'm well up into the 5s which I think is too close to the timeout of around 6 sec. My solution now feels more like dynamic programming to me with no recursion and no memoization.

I'm around 4s for that one so I guess we found almost the same thing. Here you can check my implementation. Note than half of the code is just profiling / other ideas lol.

https://bpa.st/3M7OC

And indeed it was tricky for me too. It's not specially lengthy nor requires an obscure algorithm but definitely needs having some clear ideas about the problem. I'm sure I wouldn't have pushed for that solution had you not suggested that there was a better way to do it.

All in all thanks! Maybe I'll consider doing a harder version of this one just with bigger tests (or if you want to do it, feel free to reap the xps).

The more I think about it, the more I like the idea of a Part 2. Your current test cases allow for a wide variety of solutions and I think a lot could be learned from looking at those various solutions. If I were you, I would leave your existing solution as is in the contribution so as not to give away the things we learned the past day and half.

I have another idea that might let us double the length of our already long string. If I can make that work, I'd love to take the reins and run with Part 2. I don't want to share any more than that about my new idea since I would, of course, ask you to be my validator.

By the way, our solutions are almost line for line identical, except for one thing. Where you used a default dictionary, I used a list of length (radius + 1) which then required me to use a list comprehension to find all the non zero indexes (ugh). Still, I think the fact that we eventually came up with identical algorithms is evidence that this is a powerful exercise.
Lol. I just realized you also did the array version like I did.
Nice! Also, the paste is set to expire in one week anyway so that shouldn't be an issue.

I think I'm at the end of the road (in a good way) with this exercise. I am never over 1 ms on the original 22 test cases / validators. I have no problem now doing the following consistently under 4 sec:

radius = 5280
center = 'codingameisthebestsitetopracticeyourcodingandthatistheabsolutetruth' * 5

answer = 328496258

Took: 5.2898sec
328496258

I just added an "if occ == 0: continue" to the iterative_array function previously posted. Maybe something can be done with the for loop over the 26 letters but I'm braindead atm.

So, here's where I'm at. I'm not sure I like the idea of a Part 1 and Part 2. I kind of think this is a single puzzle. - very high level medium. You start at the beginning and then your test cases lead the CodinGamer down a wonderful path of discovery that ends up somewhere in the vicinity of:

radius = 12500
center = 'codingameisthebestsitetopracticeyourcodingandthatistheabsolutetruth' * 10

answer = 993512073
(<1500 ms by the way)

Two of my absolute favorite puzzles recently are:

https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/cylinders
https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/counting-squares-on-pegs

I think you puzzle finishes out this trifecta. Your puzzle is a wonderful exercise in algorithms and optimization with a fun little catch at the end.
